verb.description: Come into being; begin or be reckoned from a particular point in time or space.
examples: we ate before the show started
below Roaring Springs the real desert starts

verb.description: Cause (an event or process) to happen.
examples: two men started the blaze that caused the explosion
those women started all the trouble

verb.description: Give a small jump or make a sudden jerking movement from surprise or alarm.

noun.description: The point in time or space at which something has its origin; the beginning.
examples: he takes over as chief executive at the start of next year
the event was a shambles from start to finish
his bicycle was found close to the start of a forest trail

noun.description: A sudden movement of surprise or alarm.
examples: the woman gave a nervous start

abbreviation.description: Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, an agreement between the US and the Soviet Union to limit and reduce strategic nuclear weapons, first signed in 1991.

phrases: don't start—I do my fair share
I've been keeping the conversation moving so Buffy here doesn't blubber, so don't you start or we'll be having to blow dry my dress.
Oh don't you start, Arcadia said.
Now don't you start, Briar replied, nudging Althia a second time and crying out when she shoved him in return.
Your mom's already gonna kick your dad out for it, don't you start too.
while I was writing this essay my computer froze and I had to start again
The weekly jazz nights will start again in February next year.
Now I can sweep the whole episode under the carpet and start again.
Kevin guessed his family didn't know she had started again.
The only way to regain full speed is to stop and start again.
origin: Old English styrtan to caper, leap, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch storten push and German stürzen fall headlong, fling. From the sense sudden movement arose the sense initiation of movement, setting out on a journey and hence beginning of a process, etc..
